data:
Stockport School is a larger than average-sized secondary school, with a designated specialism in the visual arts. The students are mostly of White British heritage; few are from minority ethnic groups, or speak English as an additional language. 

We are a Leadership Training school, and have received several awards, including Artsmark Gold, the Inclusion Quality Mark, the Basic Skills Quality Mark, Investor in People award, Young Carers in Schools Gold Award, Leading Parent Partnership Award and the International Schools full award. 

A key target of our most recent OFSTED report was to improve how we challenge pupils. This project will help us to do this as we will be challenging ourselves and will also be improving our subject knowledge and confidence, which should allow us to challenge pupils more.

We are keen to broaden the number of languages offered in the school. French and German have been taught at the school for many years, with Spanish being introduced at KS3 in September 2014 and at KS4 from September 2017.

MFL staff have good subject knowledge and are confident in their teaching. However, they need a further boost to allow them to teach the complexities of the new GCSE to a consistently high standard. They need to focus on more complex language, and hone pronunciation skills, to give our GCSE pupils excellent teaching and ensure that the use of French, German and Spanish incorporates changes in the language, new vocabulary etc. Strategically, it would also be a good idea to improve staff’s competency in their second languages, as well as the competency of non-MFL staff, in order to address staffing issues such as cover and maternity leave when they arise.

In line with the new KS3 National Curriculum and new GCSE syllabus we also need to broaden staff cultural knowledge.

Previous participants have recognised the huge benefit derived from participation in our previous project. Further immersion training will consolidate learning and boost progress in a short time.

One focus of this project will be on collaborative working between departments. As part of our first project, one non-linguist (English teacher)  took part in a mobility, and this led to excellent outcomes, including the development of materials to support primary schools. Pupils and staff have benefited from the strategy of embedding Spanish culture across the school and reinforcement of language concepts in other subject areas, increasing the European dimension. We want to build on the success of the collaboration between departments with a broader range of staff from different departments.

We plan a two-year project including 20 mobilities to take part in structured training courses in Spain. This will involve 5 teachers from the MFL department, each taking part in an immersion course in the first and second years of the project, and 10 staff from other departments across the school. We will further build on the international activities begun in the first project and increase our capacity to work more closely with our link schools.

We will continue to use eTwinning to encourage our students to learn more about European cultures and improve their language skills by communicating with pupils from across the continent.

We will focus on staff development, modernisation and internationalisation of our teaching, and  strengthening previous links we have created with other schools.

Participating staff will increase their knowledge French, German or Spanish language and culture, having an impact on their own professional development, job satisfaction and future careers.

Non-specialist staff will have the opportunity to extend and enhance their understanding of the mutual benefits of cross curricular learning. 

Participation of staff from a range of departments will have an impact on team working in our school, increasing our whole school approach to internationalisation.

We will be able to continue offering pupils a wide choice of languages to study, a consistent approach to language learning across departments, having a positive impact on pupil learning outcomes, and an enhanced curriculum involving more cross curricular working.

We will disseminate our results to our whole staff group, our pupils, our partner primary schools, non language specialist peers from other schools, disseminating our project results beyond the MFL community into other specialist areas, and via the school’s ‘Stockpress’ newsletter.

We will evaluate our project results:

for participants via use of CEF personal  reflections and creation of teaching materials based on them, reflections on our school visits and creation of teaching materials and language-teaching policies

for our pupils through reading pupils’ letters and discussing experiences with them, and joint projects folders

for our partner school via their feedback.

Classroom/pupil activities will be evaluated via lesson observation and book observations.

Our objective in doing this project are to improve attainment throughout our school in the area of languages and to offer high quality training to all our staff in order to improve their professional abilities, introducing Spanish as a new language to enhance our provision, and to enable students to build on the languages they have learned at KS2. We also want to Improve transition from KS2 to KS3, make links with teachers in Spain and France, improve cultural awareness to engage and inspire our pupils and see how languages are taught abroad to enable us to share good practice. Another of our aims is to develop creativity in language teaching and encourage collaborative working.

We would like to have seven members of staff take part in training courses in Spain or France over the course of two years. The course and will involve language learning, intercultural understanding and immersion, methodology and pedagogy and the opportunity and time in a French or Spanish school. This will develop their professional skills and improve their future prospects.

The impact we envisage from this project is an improvement in attainment within languages and better trained staff with increased professional profiles. There will be more availability of languages in our school, giving our children more choice. They will also get a better teaching experience no matter which language they choose due to our teachers improved skills. This will impact on our children’s learning and enjoyment of languages and will also give them more options for the future. 

We hope to develop strong international links and increase in contact with native speakers and eTwinning. This will lead to the development of joint projects and resources. These links will also lead to a general improvement in our cultural awareness. Teaching will generally improve as teachers’ confidence improves. There will be more creativity within our teaching and better use made of cross curricular links. Staff will develop much more confidence and will have better abilities to work in different year groups and teach different languages. They will work collaboratively and build their teamwork skills leading to better outcomes for the Department and the school.
